page.title: 05CANALS PAST AND PRESENT
page.content: Canals are made using tens of thousands of 'navvies'or 'cutters'using spades, picks,barrows,and horses.In the past canals were used to transport cargoes from one place to another.The main goods being coal,brick,wood,stone,grain or passengers. Horses were used to pull the boats at 2 m.p.h.The problems associtaed with the horses were that they needed rest and food at regular intervals.Later they were replaced by steam and eventually diesel engines.When James Brindley an engineer planned a canal route he had to uild over various obstructions.As a result aqueducts were designed to carry water over rivers,pathways,valleys,or roadways.The earliest aqueduct was built to carry the Bridgewater canal past the river Irwell at Barton.
